text: let's talk about the best zero DTE options trading strategy do you know what it is my guess is you probably don't because I don't either the fact is nobody knows there's not enough time in zero DTE to have a definitive answer but we have some pretty good ideas on what's working so far so the goal of this video is to walk you through some of the research I've been doing from my data set as well as my actual trading data and talk you through what I'm seeing that's working and what's not working and then most importantly I want to give you some ideas on how you can apply a similar methodology to figure out an approach for yourself that might work really well for you and your trading book based on your specific needs what's up everyone Eric here welcome back to the outliers shout out to the patreon family consider signing up for weekly workshops on this exact kind of stuff and let's dig right in okay so what's the profit mechanism for these trades well it's variance risk Premia and if you're unfamiliar with that concept I'll throw a link in the description below that goes through it in detail but to summarize it simply put it's the propensity for implied volatility to track above historic volatility which means that we're pricing options more richly than what they're ending up moving and we can make money off of that and because of that

text: below that goes through it in detail but to summarize it simply put it's the propensity for implied volatility to track above historic volatility which means that we're pricing options more richly than what they're ending up moving and we can make money off of that and because of that that's why I actually prefer sell style strategies for these time frames so things like short straddles strangles primarily strangles which you'll see in a little bit now let's get a quick visual on variance risk premum and essentially these yellow lines are implied volatility the white lines are historic volatility and we make money when the yellow line is above the white line and when the white line crosses above the yellow line those are typically periods that we would have a losing trade that means that in these instances the Market's priced in a lower implied volatility which we would have sold then accounted for the overall movement which was much larger than that implied volatility so let's take a look then at some of the structures that I found to work now this is kind of a cliffnotes version if we want a really in-depth version I can share something like that it would be a long video because to summarize I've traded these and tracked them both live since launch and I have a massive data set where I have essentially looked at different permutation down to single Delta variances and 5 minute entry windows and

text: looking at data sets like this one of the first things we should be eyeballing is okay where the extremes and we found the extremes pretty simply right it's these losses they're massive compared to the average wins or even the max wins on all of them so if I'm building a strategy the first thing I want to do is look at a really big data set then I want to start seeing what themes I can find and Tinker managing those and see what it does and then we need to segment the data set to make sure that we're not overfitting too much because right now we're looking at all historic data whatever we see in these tests is not going to be what happens in the future so what we need to see is how much does our management approach impact the performance of the strategies and the robustness we don't want to see a bunch of variant year-over-year because then that means that we're getting to a point where we're grossly overfitting and when we go to out of sample data set meaning going forward your performance will probably change drastically from what you back tested so we're looking for robustness here now this idea of cutting off the tails is nothing novel I'll actually throw another video in the description below that talks about this exact process and what I'm doing is looking for extremes so in this case I tinkered with a bunch

text: the 10 Deltas have grossly grossly outperformed the fives as compared to what we saw earlier why is that because we're controlling the Tails so what this is telling telling us is that if we looked at each trade in the data data sample that there are a handful of extremes that were greatly skewing our overall performance and what we cut those out specifically to the downside all of a sudden this has become a really high performing strategy the 10 and the 15 Deltas so now let's take a look at another thing which is the time of Entry again I look at essentially 5 minute increments throughout every single day but I'm giving you a slightly a bridged version for ease of following and I want you to notice a couple things we look across this data set what do you see the first thing I notice again is that everything across the board performs way better way better so this tells me again that we're on the right path and you can Tinker with all different kind of time entries but I noticed that the afternoon within a few hours of the close performs very very well so what do we see Happening Here well interestingly enough our straddles now are the top performing strategy so what's that what that's telling me is at the beginning of the day the volatility that are being priced into the straddles aren't enough to keep up with the movement

text: well so what do we see Happening Here well interestingly enough our straddles now are the top performing strategy so what's that what that's telling me is at the beginning of the day the volatility that are being priced into the straddles aren't enough to keep up with the movement throughout the day but towards the end of the day it's obviously pretty lucrative which is a very interesting find in my opinion so let's move this over one more and I want to show you the next logical look which is combining the later dat entry with the stops and what do we see well we see a couple things one the profitability on most of them actually comes down why would that be because in this case we're managing a lot of the volatility by time when you layer on something else on top of that in this case stops what's happening is throughout the end of the day you're getting getting stopped out on way too many trades that actually come back in to become winners so what this tells me is this stop is actually probably too tight so we can look at actually expanding the stop loss from 200 out to 300 and again notice what happens here we see a total expansion across the board because now we're not prematurely stopping ourselves out for trades that end up coming back in to be winning positions so the last thing I want to highlight is

text: solid performance across the board it's the 15 and the 10 Delta short strangles so you have to figure out what's right for you a couple things to consider though are for me I vary size based on how much I can quantify the risk Premia and what looks more attractive I've also started instituting a intraday volatility sampling to help me forecast what it might be throughout the rest of the day and that also uses kind of that moving average uh thesis I was talking to you about a little bit earlier if there's a big Catalyst sometimes it's worth downsizing because you're going to collect more premium anyways because of the implied volatility being so elevated and the last thing is I've started instituting a Delta rebalancing protocol in another sample of this trade it's way too early to really derive anything from that but so far that also looks promising so what's the best strategy in my opinion it would be either short premium via short straddles or short strangles you can modify the risk protocols based on what you want it's a little too early to see but for me and what I'm looking to expose myself to it's primarily looking more like short strangles although they slightly underperform there's much less year-over-year volatility in the performance of the strategy so we'll see let me know what you think in the comments below be an outlier I'll see youall later
